sections.summary: What tools should I use?Accuracy and performanceWhat can I do right now?Risk spectrumAI in CDSS: Challenges and considerations In the realm of digital health,algorithmshave long been integral to tools supporting clinical decision-making. The integration of AI brings both opportunities and challenges: AI tools offer advanced capabilities and adaptability, pushing the boundaries of what’s possible in healthcare technology. However, they also present unique challenges, particularly around transp...

sections.heading: AI Scribes

subsections.heading: AI Scribes: Know the legal and privacy risks (OMD)

sections.summary: The Ministry of Health and Ontario Health established the Ontario AI Scribe Program to support clinicians in choosing and implementing an AI scribe. Supply Ontario, with support from OntarioMD, underwent a procurement and evaluation process to establish a Vendor of Record list of AI scribe vendors that meet the clinical, business, technical, legal, and privacy requirements. The process also negotiated fair pricing for clinicians. For more information on how to get started, seeOntario AI Scrib...

sections.heading: Ethical Landscape
sections.summary: This section will be updated on an ongoing basis to track bias and potential mitigation strategies in AI-powered healthcare tools. AI models are influenced by biases from a variety of sources: Limitations of model typesBiases and lack of diversity in pre-training data and fine-tuning processBiases and lack of diversity of developers and human users

sections.heading: AI Glossary
sections.summary: AI biases result from human biases captured in training data or algorithms. They will be reflected in responses and may be overt or subtle and difficult to detect. AI Models are used to make decisions or predictions. Algorithms define the logic by which an AI model operates.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement and legal
sections.summary: The AI Learning Centre was developed using the Centre for Effective Practice’s (CEP’s) rapid knowledge translation approach as part of the Knowledge Translation in Primary Care (KTinPC) Initiative. Funded by the Ministry of Health, the KTinPC Initiative supports primary care clinicians with a series of clinical tools and health information resources. Learn more about theKTinPC Initiative.
